Object Oriented JavaScript

OOJ Intro

Object oriented JavaScript is an implementation of object-oriented programming in JS.

Basis JavaScript Object

let duck = {
    name : "Affleck",
    numLegs : 2
}; //A simple object that describes a duck named "Affleck".

Methods on an object

let dog = {
    this.name : "Benno",
    sayName : function() {
        return: "The name of this dog is " + this.name + " .";
    }
}; //Methods and functions can be placed within an object and be called from within or outside.

Create a new object

let Bird = function (name, color) {
    this.name = name;
} //Creating an object constructor called Bird (capitalized!)...

let crow = new Bird ("Jim", "black");
//Allows sub-objects to be created from the bird prototype.

Verify if an object and a contructor are related →instanceof

function House (numRooms) {
    this.numRooms = numRooms;
} //Object constructor 'House', with variable 'numRooms'.

//New Object 'myHouse' with 3 rooms:
let myHouse = new House (3);

//Verify relation
myHouse instanceof House; //Returns `TRUE`.

References to an object's own properties →this.name = name;

let Self = function (name, age) {
    this.name = name
    this.age = age,
} //To refer to an objects own property 'this.property' is used.

Prototype properties →Self.prototype.name = name;

Dog.prototype.numLegs = 2;
// Assigns `numLegs = 2` to the object `Dog`.

Add a method after inheritance

Inheritance: Objects are the core- and only contructs in JavaScript. Every working object in JS is part of the prototype chain and inherits its properties from an anchestor object.

Objects that inherit their prototype from an ancestor object can have their own exclusive methods and properties. Adding them to the descendant does not affect the ancestor.

//1. Define the parent group contructor:
function Animal () {}

//2. Add a new method to the parent group:
Animal.prototype.eat = function () {
    console.log("nom nom nom");
};

//3. Define a new animal `Dog`:
function Dog () {}

//4. Let `Dog` inherit all properties from animal:
Dog.prototype = Object.create(Animal.prototype);

//5. Convert `Dog` to a constructor:
Dog.prototype.constructor = Dog;

//6. Add an exclusive method to `Dog` object constructor
Dog.prototype.bark = function () {
    console.log("Woof!");
};

Override inheritance methods

It is possible to change properties and methods of an inheriting object, shown in the steps below.

//1. Define animal object;
function Animal(){}

//2. Add a method:
Animal.prototype.eat = function(){
    console.log("nom nom nom");
};

//3. Define a new object `Bird`:
function Bird(){}

//4. Apply Animal methods to Bird:
Bird.prototype = Object.create(Animal.prototype);

//5. Override `Animal.eat()` for `Bird`:
Bird.prototype.eat = function() {
    console.log("peck peck");
};

Use a Mixin to add common behaviours between unrelated objects

let flyMixin = function(obj) {
    obj.fly = function () {
        this.fly = true;
    };
} //Creates a method which adds the property of `fly` to the variable obj.

//Two different objects
let bird = { name: "Donald", numLegs: 2 }

let plane = { name: "Boeing-737", passengers: 524}

//Both receive the same property by the `flyMixin()` method.
flyMixin(bird);
flyMixin(plane);

Use closure to protect properties within an object

Using closures in your code prevents properties within an object from being modified from outside.

An additional method within the object containing the closure makes it possible for the private variable value to be made public.

//Define object `Bird`
function Bird(){

    //Define a PRIVATE VARIABLE
    let hatchedEggs = 10;

    //Method to make `hatchedEggs` PUBLIC:
    this.getHatchedCount = function() {
        return hatchedEggs; //returns a public variable
    }
}

Immediately invoked function expression →IIFE

An IIFE declares and immediately executes a function or method. The trick is to wrap the function declaration within parenthesis and then call it, like so:

( function + definition )( );

( function() {
    console.log("Action");
})();

Using IIFE to create a module

Using an IIFE the method below is immediately executed as soon as it is defined.

let motionModule = ( function() {
    return
        glideMixin: function(obj) {
            obj.glide = function () {
                console.log("Gliding!");
            };
        },
        flyMixin: function(obj) {
            obj.fly = function () {
                console.log("Flying!");
            }
        }
})();
